B000022TSV|5.0|Francesco Rosi, in much the same manner as Franco Zefferelli, directed a stunning and dramatic film about a popular opera. As with Verdi's La Traviata, Carmen is one of those mainstream, instantly recognizable and popular operas that even people who do not have in-depth knowledge or appreciation of opera. Georges Bizet's opera was based on the novella by Prosper Merimee, about a seductive Gypsy named Carmen who lures an innocent Spanish soldier (Don Jose) to a life of crime. When Carmen falls for a bullfighter, (Escamillo) she jilts him, but he becomes so jealous that he stabs Carmen in a crime of passion.<br /> The powerful emotions, as well as sexy Spanish tunes, were all beautifully composed by Georges Bizet. The role of Carmen is a mezzo soprano role, but many sopranos have tried their hand at the alluring heroine- she is, quite frankly, opera's most liberal, independent and modernistic heroines. Maria Callas, Beverly Sills, Tatiana Troyanos, Grace Bumbry and Shirley Verret have most notably performed the roles successfully. In the Rosi film, shot on location in Seville and other parts of Spain, Carmen is portrayed by Julia Migenes Johnson. It has been said before, Julia Migenes Johnson, although Spanish herself, could not capture the true essece of Bizet's heroine. <br />Her voice is not suited for the feisty, sexy heroine and although she must have practiced considerably, she fails to become the fatal Carmen. Julia's voice is not pretty, not does it sound \\"French\\", or Spanish for that matter. Her only successful parts come at the end, in which she confronts Don Jose at the bullfight, dressed elegantly in red and meets her death at his hands. The very scene is symbolic. At the bullfight, Escamillo, Carmen's new lover, is fighting a bull, and just as he stabs the bull to its death, Don Jose stabs Carmen to her death. Carmen is herself as free and untamed as the bull, and only the domineering, jealous, crazed Don Jose could end her life and terminate that freedom.<br />Of all the performances in the film, Placido Domingo as Don Jose is the most gratifying. A true actor, Placido immerses himself in the character, becoming the romantic, jealous and dark soldier whose obscession for Carmen becomes a sort of madness. Placido Domingo is the modern Enrico Caruso. Few tenors have his dramatic potential combined with great rich tenor vocal qualities. Ruggero Raimondi is the baritone who portrays Escamillo, and he does it very successfully. A handsome, earthy man, he fits the role of the boastful, macho bullfighter that wins Carmen's attentions. Faith Esham sings the role of Micaela, a character in Bizet's opera but not in the Merimee novella. Micaela is the beautiful, sedate, modest Christian young woman whom Don Jose is engaged to marry, but the woman he abandons for the more exciting and seductive Carmen. The cinematography of the film is lush, realistic and symbolic. The musical score finely arranged and conducted. As a film, this opera makes for great drama. Music classes should even see this film for some kind of lesson plan. It is also one of Placido Domingo's greatest roles, some would say the greatest.
B00008IAMD|5.0|this is a great record, with great attention to musical and &quot;spirtual detail&quot;. it is one of the records i heard in a long while.. great cover to cover thanks!

Denuncia soterrada de la represin, hipocresa y bajeza de los &quot;ganadores&quot; de la guerra.

But on their follow up, they really improved a lot.<br />While this album still isn't knock-your-socks-off amazing, its decent enough. It has one outstanding track, and several decent ones, and a bunch of filler with one or two annoying tracks.<br />&quot;Daylight&quot; really stands out as the best track. The swooping guitar, the cushion of bass and piano and the contrasting driving drums in the verses really lends a sense of drama to this song, while Martin's voice hovers monotonically over the whole thing. Seeing them live, Martin's antics on piano and mike basically took up the entire stage, while the rest of the band stood in place and played way in the background.

I was extremely pleased with the results. I saw the remaster projected in San Antonio in March 2001 and was blown away. It definitely looked and sounded superior to what I remember in 1978. I sent about 100 pounds of photos and promotional items to Warner Bros. for consideration in the documentaries/supplemental section of the DVD. A lot was used, however, a stills gallery was rejected because WB wanted to stay with a one disc, dual-sided DVD package. I decided to create the CapedWonder website to showcase the images that didn't make it on the DVD. The crisp, wet scanned print will erase every memory you ever had of what this film looked like. The restored scenes will broaden your understanding of what the film was about. My favorite songs include Bring Me To Life, Everybody's Fool, Going Under, and Tourniquet, but then again they're all great. If you wanna make a smart decision, buy this cd!!

B000089RVX|5.0|In an age where many newer bands run the same sound and rhetoric, reminding us that grunge really is dead, Evanescence is a breath of new life into the mainstream. With their major label debut, Fallen, they stand distinguished among the neo-punks and Creed [copies] that define today's pop rock.<br />Ben Moody sets the dark, savage tone of the album with grinding guitar riffs. Amy Lee balances the sensor shattery with her beautiful, yet haunting vocals. Together with the piano talents of David Hodges, drum work by Josh Freese, and bassist Francesco DiCosmo, Evanescence defy their name through their music.<br />The songs are pieces of tragic poetry, beautiful and chilling. They tell of pain, desperation, and loss, with a hint of inner strength and resolve. You may find yourself moved to tears through the longing words of My Immortal, or even relating Everybody's Fool to a previous relationship.<br />Moving onto a major label and making a mainstream release has not changed the tone of Evanescence one bit. In the end this may not bode well when it comes to radio play, but talent like this does not go unnoticed forever, nor does it burn out under the spotlight. This album is worth every penny and more, and worth your listen.

B000063DIH|3.0|Let me cut to the chase with this review and state right off the bat that this is not vintage maiden, this is a maiden lost in transition and coming to an end of an era.  All was not well in the Maiden camp, tensions were fray between Steve Harris  and Bruce Dickinson due to conflicting views in musical direction and new guitarist Janik Gers was getting flack for his off the wall style which was uncomplimentary with Dave Murray's.  Also metal was coming back down to earth following the glory days of the 1980s but all this was nothing as for the complete demise of Maiden in the early 90s could be summed up in two words - Adrian Smith. Smith was a key player in the songwriting department and his superior controlled and highly melodic style along with the telepathic understanding with life time friend Dave Murray was the soul of Maiden's sound.<br />Following the disastrous 'No prayer for the dying' there had to be some improvement and there was, but sadly very little. Things starting well with the flying opener 'be quick or be dead' great sound, heavy and great lyrics, good ol' anti-capitalist stuff.  It is here we are introduced to Bruce Dickinson's raspy, deeper vocals which are a clear indication maiden are going for more linear metal to take after their pinnacle metal/prog achievement 'Seventh Son of a Seventh Son' which was a masterpiece. The second song 'From here to Eternity underlines Maidens new direction, flirting with the girls, bikes and leather metal styling, this song me be a semi-spoof but to the untrained eye it's just hair metal, something Maiden thankfully never were. This feel is incorporated over into 'fear is the key', 'wasting love', 'chains of misery', 'Judas be my guide' and 'weekend warrior' which are so utterly dreadful they get the prize for being the lowest of the low on any Maiden album. On these songs The melodies are straight forward and predictable, vocally and lyrically uninspiring and Janik's soloing as masturbatory at times, simply awful.<br />However if it wasn't for 3 outstanding all time Maiden classics which can be found on this album I would be e-mailing Amazon to put in a minus star rating option.  The songs 'Be quick or be Dead', 'Afraid to shoot Strangers' and the epic 'Fear of the Dark' make the album worthwhile. Based on the gulf war track 3 'Afraid to shoot stranger's is both musically and lyrically beautiful with a poetic feel in it's melody and energising explosion in the middle, basically war is put to music, and it's fantastically done. <BR>From here on in your sitting through some very average and at times awful music and your wondering what the hell is going on until 'Fear of the Dark' hits. Wow, what a song, a classic all time metal anthem rises from the dust of the album and packs one hell of a punch. From the epic opening lines to the immensely energetic explosion it grabs hold and doesn't let go, even Janik manages to pull of a blinder of a solo, feel, energy, killer riffs and a sing along chorus you cannot go wrong.<br />Overall this album is poor by Maiden standards and for me the made the wrong choice for regressing to a kind of Americanised biker hair metal theme. Also as we all know things went from bad to worse after this album although the story did have a happy ending with the reunion of Bruce and Adrian and the brilliant 'Brave new World' and they found the Maiden of old, forever may it prosper.
B00005JKDR|4.0|Just saw MONSTERS INC. for the first time, and although I wasn't looking forward to some of the cutsy schmaltz that sometimes overly pervades certain Disney films, the entrancing--and vivid--computer animation totally sucked me in, so much that I soon couldn't care less about whatever corny little story the screenwriters were trying to make me believe.  <br />However, a funny thing happened during my ongoing visual and aural animation: I actually started caring about the story, about the characters created only from photons and actors' voices--as well as from a screenplay that is completely inoffensive to little ears, yet also listenable to bigger ones. And the graphics--wow! At times I found myself forgetting that this wasn't live-action, especially during what I felt was the best scene, one that reminded me of a wicked inverted-rollercoaster ride. <br />Well, there you have it: a film that everyone from five and up can enjoy, for different aspects of it.  Aside from the wonderful visuals, of course we also get two of the best vocal acting performances in recent memory, from Billy Crystal and John Goodman. Yes, we also get some of those patented Disney/Pixar fake 'outtakes' during the closing credits (I know they're a bit corny by now, but they're still kind of cute).  With all of the extras on the DVD, I'd say it's a good buy--whether you have a kid or not.  HIGHLY RECOMMENDED

B00008976Y|5.0|It goes to this film's infinite praise to state that the gripping plot is a mere by-product of Kielowski's aesthetic vision.  \\"Blue\\" is an impressionist painting in motion; a cinematic experience of objects and faces immersed in shadows and pulsating hues.  Seductively textured in this film is the title: blue is the faint glaze of a suit worn by a man at a funeral; blue are the bare walls in a deserted home; blue is the twilight reflected on a child's crystal lamp, and the scribbled notes on an unfinished composition; blue is the tattered facade behind a flute player out in the street. \\"Blue\\" is the portrait of a woman hardened by tragedy, but redeemed by music.  <br />Watch this film, and relish every image the draws you in. It's what people do when beholding a work of pure genius.

B00006JL1Z|5.0|Having been a fan of Christine McVie since seeing Fleetwood Mac on the Bare Trees tour, I was really none too thrilled with all of the hoopla that surrounded the band when Stevie Nicks and Lindsey Buckingham joined the group in the late seventies. Being a progressive music snob at the time, I also could not relate to their lyrics either, so I almost turned a deaf ear to their music (the only reason that I had any later period Fleetwood Mac in my collection was to satisfy the tastes of several girlfriends). Now older, wiser, and more experienced in life, I picked up this jewel on a whim. The choice and order of songs are fantastic, and the remastering job is top notch. Comparing song titles with the original releases, this one is really all you need if you have no Fleetwood Mac at all in your collection. It has all of the songs from &quot;Greatest Hits&quot; (with a better live version of I'm So Afraid) plus a superb choice of additional cuts. As for the original albums &quot;Fleetwood Mac&quot; and &quot;Rumours&quot;, this release renders getting those albums as somewhat useless, as only a few of the more obscure cuts on those two releases have been wisely omitted from this collection. From &quot;Tusk&quot; up until 2002, only the cream of the crop is included in this collection. The results of this collection make it sound almost like a brand new release instead of being a quarter of a century old. Now if only a collection could be compiled for either all of Christine McVie's songs or the transitional period leading up to the period represented by this collection (Bare Trees-Mystery To Me-Heroes Are Hard To Find). As for fans of the original bluesy Fleetwood Mac, this collection is probably not for you.

B00006HBUA|2.0|Given the stars involved, the hilarity of the old cartoons, and the big budget, Scooby Doo should have been a sure fire hit.  Unfortunately, it was just another example of filmmakers trying to buy quality with special effects.  <br />The acting was the first disappointing factor about this dreadful mess of a movie.  Teenybopper king Freddie Prinze Jr. plays Fred with over-the-top cockiness, and for some reason decided to make the character appear to be gay!  Sarah Michelle Gellar was slightly better, but not by much.  Her Daphne has a bad case of \\"valley girl\\" syndrome, and like Prinze, Gellar overacts, which is completely unlike her.  Linda Cardelinni as Velma was a decent decision.  Though she didn't contribute much, she didn't ham it up like the rest of the cast.  The only instance where these over the top screwball antics were completely acceptable was in Matthew Lillard's Shaggy.  Lillard must have watched the old cartoons for months, because his Shaggy is dead on, and he interacts with the CGI Scooby just as the cartoon did thirty years ago.<br />The plot is too ludicrous for words.  In short, the four get into a big scuffle in the beginning of the film, and they go their separate ways.  Well, of course they end up having to get back together to solve one last mystery a few months later.  They set off to a tropical island with a creepy amusement park where college coeds are being turned into zombies.  The normal hijinx occur, and its up to our heros to save the day. <br />The biggest problem with this film wasn't the acting, or the ridiculous plot.  It was the fact that the movie couldn't decided who it wanted to cater to.  There were some absolutely hilarious moments of innuendo dealing with the urban legends that surround the cartoon, but these moments were few and far between.  For instance, there is a scene in which the mystery machine is shown with smoke billowing out the windows, while Shaggy and Scooby are heard laughing hysterically, addressing the rumor that the quartet was constantly stoned.  A few seconds later, we just see that the two are barbequing inside the van.  Humorous moments like this one are a rarity, as we have to sit through low brow farting humor most of the time.  The filmmakers should have decided in the beginning whether they were going to target older audiences, or go for a new generation of Scooby fans.  The constant jumping back and forth is quite annoying.<br />The lone highlights of this wretched film are Lillard's performance as Shaggy, and the Outkast song \\"Land of a Million Drums\\", which is featured on the soundtrack.  <br />If you were a die hard fan of the cartoons, this may interest you.  For those who were just casual viewers, it was certainly nothing special.  The only ones guarenteed to love it are kids between the ages of 5 and 12.  Do yourself a favor and avoid this one if at all possible.

Pick up Power To Believe.<br />On the first listen, I thought &quot;ah yes, THIS is what rock used to be about!&quot; Excllent hooks, masterful percussion and an inescapable catchiness that makes you want to thrash about the room. I'll say up front that unlike many other reviewers here, I liked Crimson's last offer: Construktion of Light. The new album is in that league and beyond.<br />I don't miss Bruford one bit on this album. Mastelotto's electronic persussion work to me is more inspiring and more on the cutting edge than what I've heard from Bruford lately. Likewise, I don't even miss Tony Levin on bass. Trey Gunn is masterful on his Warr guitar, belting out extremely low-end bass that drives these energetic tracks forward.<br />Of course, it goes without saying that Fripp is a guitar genius who never fails to deliver. For a guy edging towards 60, he's teaching the whippersnappers the meaning of true rock musicianship. This is how it's done, kids. Take a lesson.<br />What's the only thing that I would have liked more of on this album? A little more space for Belew's lyrics and vocals. Not a tremendous amount of voice work on this one, but this is a minor point.

6303482295|5.0|This video is one of the &quot;Super Cities&quot; series produced by the International Video Network, which consists of one-half hour tapes of 22 of the more interesting cities in the world. They are, far and away, the best travel videos that I have seen.<br />The approach that the producers take is to mix aerial and ground footage in roughly 50/50 proportions. This approach is especially effective for Budapest, which is actually two cities (Buda and Pest) divided by the Danube.<br />What comes across is what must be an exceptionally pleasant city to live in, especially in the summer, with numerous parks and outdoors cafes. While there are some interesting sights, however, they are limited in both number and quality. As a result, I took Budapest off my list of places to visit.<br />That, of course, is one of the things that a good travel video should do--provide you with enough information to make an intelligent decision as to whether or not to visit a place.<br />The Super Cities series also includes a tape on Istanbul, which is similar to Budapest (in mixing elements of East and West), but is a far more interesting city. That tape is also excellent, the only difference being that it will convince you that you want to visit Istanbul.

B000001EXR|5.0|Ok, first off -- whoever that knucklehead was who cited &quot;Hotter Than Hell&quot; as being among Kiss' weakest albums.....get your head out of your a**.<br />&quot;Carnival of Souls&quot; may be a bit heavier than the &quot;classic&quot; Kiss sound, and yes, it may sound somewhat calculated to fit in with the mid-90's sound, but SO WHAT?!?  Haven't Kiss been changing with the times since day one?  Didn't they explore disco?  Hair metal?  Sometimes they succeed, sometimes they fail.  The bottom line is, the people who criticize this album rarely mention the tunes themselves, only the style of the music.  This takes 1992's &quot;Revenge&quot; to the next level.  <br />While this album does not scale the heights of &quot;Destroyer&quot;, it ranks as the band's best effort since &quot;Creatures of the Night&quot; in 1982....if not &quot;Love Gun&quot; in '77.  Catchy, melodic and (gasp!) CREATIVE tunes are abundant -- this stuff is more thought out and interesting than your average Kiss material.  I'm not saying I would love it if all of their stuff was like this -- the fact that Kiss' music is mindless and fun is one of its greatest strengths.  But this is a nice change up from the usual &quot;party&quot; songs. <br />Yes, you will find stuff that sounds vaguely reminicent of Soundgarden on here, but the songwriting also invokes the likes of The Beatles and Led Zeppelin on several tracks.  Plain and simple, it is Kiss' most grown up &amp; respectable efforts EVER.

B000002MU3|4.0|Since R.E.M. started in the early 80's, they've built a very huge career from the diversity of their smalltown, Athens, Georgia. Nevertheless, this album would absolutely be a difficult one to make. On this album, R.E.M. had to go out on tour for, and not look back. It would be a tour, and a record they would never, ever forget.<br />The 1994 album, Monster went multi-platinum within a matter of a few months, and the music went back to the hard feel that R.E.M. was known for. The songs still blend in with hard rock, and a couple of power ballads on the side. The music still is as powerful, with What's The Frequency Kenneth?, Bang And Blame, and Strange Currencies. But, the record also had a much more understanding meaning behing it, as R.E.M. dedicated the record to River Phoneix, who died of a drug overdose in 1993.<br />Unfortunately, Monster would be the next-to-last album R.E.M. would perform with Bill Berry. His abrupt exit from the band would change R.E.M. into a trio, and change the feel of their music for good. If you're a true R.E.M. fan, I suggest you get this album.

B00004Z459|4.0|I have since forgotten how long ago I bought this cd, but when I first bought it, it was constantly in my cd player. Now it manages to sneak in every now and then, only because I've sort of outgrown the feeling the cd gives off. However, at the time, I felt I could relate to a lot of the lyrics and the feelings the songs gave off.<br />Because I'm not all that great with words, I'll just be blunt and give you a review of the cd song by song.<br />Track 1 - Papercut: I think this song has a good beginning (I think the beginning of the first song on a cd is incredibly important - it builds you up and lets you know what you're in for with the rest of the cd), and the lyrics are so-so. Final rating? I'd say 2 1/2 stars.<br />Track 2 - One Step Closer: This was a favorite of mine, until it got massive airplay and you heard it on every radio station and every time you turned on MTV. Still, before it got played out, it was a great song. Final rating: 1 1/2 (only because it's played out and I'm sick of hearing it).<br />Track 3 - With You: One of the songs I really related to, and still do (I thought it explained my feelings towards my ex quite well). I honestly have nothing to say about it (and if I did, I'd probably start rambling about my ex, and I'm sure you'd much rather hear about the cd than my ex :P ). Final rating: 3 stars<br />Track 4 - Points of Authority: Ahh, this brings back memories of driving around with my good friend and her trying to imitate the wierd way Mike Shinoda says \\"forfit\\". (She still hasn't gotten it, by the way.) I honestly have nothing to say about this song. It's not one of my favorite tracks, it's not one I dislike. Final rating: 3 stars<br />Track 5 - Crawling: Ugh, if I hear this song or see the video one more time, I will march down to MTV myself and hurt someone. This song had massive amounts of my respect until they released it. Now I'm so sick of it. It's a disappointment that they released it - it used to be my song, now it's everyoneelse's song. My advice? Listen to it once and then skip over it from then on. Final rating: 2 stars<br />Track 6 - Runaway: I absolutely love this song. The beginning and the way it builds you up is awesome. And the lyrics are awesome... For some reason this song always brings me back to times I had forgotten, times when I was in fact running away from whatever was haunting me. And it always reminds me of night time for some reason... Final rating: 4 1/2 stars<br />Track 7 - By Myself: Another song I can still relate to. The lyrics are great, not just the chorus but all the verses. Final rating: 4 stars<br />Track 8 - In The End: Again, as with One Step Closer and Crawling, I used to have respect for this song before it got released. However, it hasn't gotten as much airplay, so it's not that annoying as of yet. However, don't expect that to last long. Final rating: 2 1/2 stars<br />Track 9 - A Place For My Head: This is my favorite track on the cd. The beginning...can't explain it, but it's awesome. And the sort of fast way he sings sounds cool. Lyrics are awesome. The chorus is even better. Used to blast this when I'd get mad at my parents. Good for getting out aggression. Final rating: 5 stars (I'd give it more if I could!)<br />Track 10 - Forgotten: Nice to hear a song that starts with lyrics instead of music. Lots of aggression and gets you revved up. Takes a while for the chorus to come up, but it's worth it.<br />Track 11 - Cure For The Itch: A good song, but I usually fast forward about 54 seconds (where the mood slows down and the piano comes in). It's cool to chill to, but doesn't lose any feeling. It's sort of an intermission, if you will, so you can relax for a minute. Final rating: 4 1/2 stars<br />Track 12 - Pushing Me Away: All in all, a good song...not one of my favorites, but whatever. Final rating: 3 stars<br />All in all, this is a good cd worth owning if you have the extra bucks around to buy it. If not, find a friend with a cd burner, hehe. :P

0679879269|3.0|I can't recall another trilogy in which I so enjoyed the first two volumes (see my earlier reviews) and was so thoroughly disappointed in the finale. Lyra (now called Silvertongue) and Will Parry are back in Lyra's world this time, gearing up for the final battle between Good and Evil, trying to reach Lord Asriel, who commands the forces of humankind against the malevolence of God. Lyra was kidnapped by her mother at the end of Book 2 and has now been stashed in the Himalayas, and Will has to rescue her. He just happens to meet up with the migrating armored bears, who promise to help. Will's long lost father also has a key role -- there's no such thing as a chance encounter in this universe -- and so is Dr. Mary Malone from our own world. So far, so good. But by the halfway point in the narrative, we're involved with angels who have very human characteristics and whom I found totally unbelievable as what they are supposed to be, and the pace has slowed to a frustrating crawl. Frankly, I couldn't finish the book, which was very upsetting after all the time I invested in the story and the pleasure I drew from it until now.

The album has swirling guitars, catchy hooks, and a great amount of depth from songs which blast you off with a burst of energy like \\"The Bends\\" to melodic and haunting songs which evoke memories like \\"High and Dry\\" and my personal favorite \\"Black Star.\\"<br /><br />If I could choose three words to descibe this album I would submit:  Passion, Exploration, and Remorse.<br /><br />I could not give an album a higher rating. The album somehow releases an energy and sensitivity which is unmatched by any other band or album I have heard.  There simply is not a bad song on the album and the only way to truly experience the depth of the songs and the reaches of this album is to listen at least once all the way through.<br /><br />Some of the songs like \\"Street Spirit\\" and \\"My Iron Lung\\" have such beauty and contradiction in their styles.  \\"My Iron Lung\\" takes you on a journey through several types of music but still maintains a common feeling, and I think the song \\"Street Spirit\\" ends the album on a softer, floating back down to earth feeling that seems to perfectly end the voyage of this album.<br /><br />You have been warned. B00006JJ1O|3.0|Who are T.A.T.U? Two teenage lesbian singers from Russia and of course, the latest pop sensation all over the world. <BR>   Through the 12 tracks of their English debut they mix elements from pop and dance with  infrequent strength. Their sound is quite different to everything else out there, and I must admit that some songs are amazing. Still, there's a big problem...is this an lp or ep?...let's count the tracks...there are 12 at first sight...but...they are only 8 really. Because it contains the Russian version to \\"Not gonna get us\\" and \\"All the things she said\\", then there is an extended version of \\" Show me love\\" ( which is totally unnecessary) plus the remix of \\"30 minutes\\" which is weak.<BR>   On their first single, the powerful and sexy \\"All the things she said\\" they sing about what it feels like loving someone of your same sex. In this song in particular their voices sound sweet in the verses and hard in the chorus, which gives the track a split sound which is really interesting.<BR>   While most of the lyrics are about love, often they hold a twist just to say how hard it is going through their situation because they are in a position which many people do not accept.<BR>   Julia and Lena sing in a way which is not very common, they have girl voices which sound angelically at times and strident at others. They can handle the vocals pretty well, though their songs may be difficult to sing to an average person.<BR>   Other standout moments are \\"Show me love\\" which goes in a similar way to \\"All the things she said\\" ( the best the disc has to offer), and \\"30 minutes\\" which sees T.A.T.U. all calmed down with a pretty little background music.<BR>   The album includes  an enhanced section which features the video to \\"All the things she said\\" and behind the scenes with Lena and Julia.<BR>   T.A.T.U. with their unique sound will be the next big thing, though they will have to find better  ( and more!) songs since nothing on the album is half as good as their first single.

The lyrics are powerful, and are sure to bring about Christina-sympathizers. For example, the words, \\"It's not so easy to forget, all the marks you left along her neck/When I was thrown against cold stairs/ And everyday afraid to come home in fear of what I might see, next...\\" are some of such seriousness that are nowhere to be found previous works. <BR> One of the highlights of the album is what seems to be Aguilera's indirect payback at superstar rapper Eminem, who has been known to shoot out low blows at Aguilera. In \\"Can't Hold Us Down,\\" the up-beat second track of \\"Stripped,\\" Aguilera says, \\"So he does what every little boy would do/ Making up a few false rumors or two/ That for sure is not a man to me, slanderin' names for popularity/ It's sad you only get your fame through controversy...\\" She even goes on to say, \\"You must talk so big to make up for smaller things,\\" which leaves to the imagination what \\"things\\" she is talking about. However, Aguilera shows good taste in not mentioning Eminem's name and keeping the payback subtle. This song is one of the catchiest on the CD, as song centers around a woman's image, as well as featuring female rapper Lil' Kim. In the song, Aguilera also gripes about men being praised for sexual successes, while women are deemed \\"whores\\" in similar behavior. \\"Can't Hold Us Down\\" is sure to be a hit if it is released as a single. <BR> Throughout the album, Aguilera belts out lyrics about her image, one that has gone downhill since she has come out of her shell. Lately Aguilera has been three-fourths naked in public, and her raunchy video, \\"Dirrty\\" has brought around negative talk about her change for the worse, as well as her appearance on the cover of Rolling Stone,which showed Aguilera wearing nothing but black boots and a guitar. If anything, this sort of publicity will probably hurt album sales. The caliber of music on \\"Stripped\\" has proved that her gimmicky provocative style is unnecessary. <BR> The bottom line is, don't let this dramatic change in her image keep you from listening to this album. Or at least downloading a couple of the songs. This is just another example that some girls are truly meant to be heard, but not seen.

This is a Samuel Goldwyn film that is as enchanting and fulfilling as anything to ever come from Hollywood.  The bishop is being pressured to build a cathedral by a society matron (Gladys Cooper - who even in her late thirties was always playing somebody's widow or mother) and has no time for his wife.  Dudley (Grant) is an angel, the answer to the bishop's prayer that turns out to be his greatest obstacle when he takes a sudden interest in Julia (Young). <BR>Previously released by HBO Home Video, this MGM edition appears to be the same disappointing transfer as before.  Gray scale and contrast and black levels are weak.  Digital compression artifacts crop up now and then and edge enhancement and aliasing problems make for a real frustrating viewing experience.  The sound has been matrixed by CHACE INC. into a sudo-stereo mix.  The original mono is also included for the film purist.  Both are strident and lacking in tonal quality and bass.  There's a theatrical trailer included but nothing that will set the world on fire or enhance your love of this holiday classic.  I suppose the one saving grace of the film is the film itself - with Grant, Young and Niven at the helm, the first time viewer is guaranteed an enchantingly good time.

B00006C79E|1.0|For some reason, I rarely see a bad review of a Saint Etienne CD.  No other band, in my opinion recieves such positive press from both fans, and critics alike.  I expected Finisterre to be the album that would change the opinions of many who held previous Saint Etienne records in high regard.  Alas, this is  not the case, and I'm a bit suprised. <br />Finisterre has some great songs on it, but none of them manage to capture the spirit, atmosphere and emotion of previous efforts.  Take for example Saint Etienne classics such as 'Mario's Cafe' and 'Your in a Bad Way'; both have an almost undefinable emotional quality about them.  They are songs that bring out moods and melodies that made us fans of the group in the first place. <br />Let us not also forget the classic 'Good Humor'.  Quite possibly the bands best effort to date.  All the tracks on that disc have that special Saint Etienne signature sound that stirs the imagination and the soul each and every time you listen to it. <br />But Finisterre, evokes no such emotion.  To me, the album is trying to hard to re-create New Wave 80's pop with a modern twist.  Some tracks manage quite well in this effort, but at what cost?  In an effort to create a more experimental sound, I believe the band have sacraficed the elements of their music that set them in a class of their own.  <br />Where are the lush strings on Finisterre?  The playful flutes?  What about the beautiful piano melodies?  Where is the nostalgia of the 1970's?  To me, these are some of the elements that make up the soul of Saint Etienne, and Finisterre simply does not have it.
0517122707|5.0|In fact, this novel is so good it is now one of my most favorites, even though my first impression of the book was that trying it was a mistake.<br />I had recently been disappointed by another novel, Catch-22.  A Confederacy of Dunces had the same light, comical tone as Catch-22, but the subject of it, Ignatius P. Reilly, was a character more grotesque (it seemed to me) than any of the numerous annoying characters in Catch-22.  I was expecting the worst.<br />However, as I read on, I gradually and unconsciously began to really enjoy the story.  The novel quickly developed an interesting main plot, along with many interesting subplots.  I met many characters, and found myself very interested in them and  in what would happen to them.  The writing style was excellent, and there were some sections where the writing was awesome (such as the section where we first meet Dr. Talc).  The novel was also very funny.<br />The best part of this novel was the ending, where all the little subplots fall together into a great conclusion.  I think it's one of the best endings ever.  (I've seen some reviewers call this a canned Hollywood ending.  It isn't, any more than the ending of, say, The Tempest was.  The ending was well supported by the story.)<br />In addition to being a highly engaging book with a great ending, there was a kind of indescribable unity to it, that was very delightful.  I guess the best way I can put it is that all the characters shared a common &quot;dunceness&quot; that made them all somehow related to each other.<br />Basically, I think this was just a great novel.
B00008BXJF|5.0|First off, while The Construkction of Light album was not their best and the live three disc Heavy Construkction showed some promise it wasn't until King Crimson released the crushing EP Level 5 that we got a good idea of this iterration of KC coming together. Then another teaser of sorts, the Happy With What You Have To Be Happy With EP gave us a closer studio based glimpse of the current direction of King Crimson and finally, The Power To Believe.<br />TPTB is the most cohesive and varied work in the entire King Crimson catalog. If you are a fan and are willing to be open minded you will hear it. The choice of vocoder on The Power To Believe 1: A Cappella is a clue things are different. From this almost sci-fi intro we are slammed with Level Five, a heaping slab of molten metal. This is not your average prog metal band or any metal band. This is a skilled unit of artists that had time to craft and work on a direction to play and you get to be introduced to this new direction. Level Five sums up King Crimson. It is precise, dense polyrhthmic metal that any competent player could learn to play but not compose. The riffs are massive the lead guitar work stunning. We are listening to a statement from the elder statesmen of three decades of music. They certainly don't seem ready to hand over the throne.<br />Eyes Wide Open brings the tension down to the kind of quiet song you wish more people would play. It is devoid of showmanship and pomp, it is a beautifully arranged song that could (but won't) get airplay. Imagine Sting when he still had fire in him with a better backup band and you have a good idea. <br />Elektrik starts in a ambient mode evolving into King Crimson's 'nuevo' metal and setting up Facts of Life, another view of contemporary sound that is still based in fundemental - classic songwriting. When 2003's artists sound ages in 10 years King Crimson will still sound fresh. Almost all of their material ages well and that holds true on TPTB.<br />The title track returns in a new form, an evolution that features guitar synths and eventually a big sound. It's hard to classify King Crimson and near impossible on this CD.<br />Dangerous Curves is as good a description for the song as any. The playing is stunning. Every musician is part of the mesh which was not so on The Construkction of Light CD. Behind the creative writing, arrangment and performance is a band that knows one another, has that groove that 80's KC had and the ability to drop on a dime like the mid 70's KC did.<br />This was evident on the last studio CD but this time out it's not the Fripp and Belew show. Every track here is in it's place for a reason and written with care, craft and conviction. Often King Crimson can be a cold sounding band. Even if they thrill or impress they do not always move us. The tone of every vocal track here is sincere. Even Happy With What You Have To Be Happy With has a playful, lightly sarcastic look that sure sounds like a little snipe at critics of Belew's lyrics.<br />The Power to Believe III is yet another soundscape at first, one that builds and releases tension in a classic art rock way ending with the Coda.<br />You don't listen to The Power To Believe, you absorb it, or more likely it absorbs you. The sounds are varied in a way that King Crimson hasn't done - period. The drums are vastly better sounding. I work with a drummer who has V-Drums. They do not have to sound like drum machines. And the drums don't except where warranted on the album. The use of several types of ambiences, from spacy textures to industrial noise mixed with the highly structured arppegiations and counter rhythms are a big turn for King Crimson. They have looked at the modern world and after dabbling a bit taken a sizeable leap while remaining true to their musical values.<br />The Power To Believe will be considered one of King Crimson's defining moments and one of their best, I think. Any band that can play achingly beautiful music (Eyes Wide Open) and wack you with uber-metal frenzy (Level Five) deserves some slack when listening. I can imagine luddite fans stuck at the 80's band. Well, for those who have been waiting for the album that moves to the next level, here it is. The 90's and prevous 00's music was very good but these songs are great and are the most cohesive in theme and continuity. <br />Here is the one critical issue. Fripp seems to be fixated with arppegiations and specific pitchs. As a result some might initially find some of this material to be similar to older material. But it seems to me this is the most democratic version of King Crimson. The thing that elevates TPTB are the ensemble segments and incredibly tasteful drumming and tap guitar. In fact, the use of the Warr guitar enables KC to have three guitarists or one guitar synth and complementary dual guitars. Trey Gunn is greatly underappreciated. If you can grab the Deja Vroom DVD or watch the 40 minute video on disc 2 of the Heavy Construkction CD you'll see how important Gunn is and how annoying those drums could sound. The use of (I'm guessing) traditional and electronic drums is a much better choice and results in some tasty playing and Pat getting a chance to be part of the ambience which is common to electronic artists but almost antithical to a band as overwhelmingly intense as King Crimson can be.<br />Buy the CD, if you don't like it give it a chance it's really a great work, one I've been waiting for as a fan some 20+ years.

0375703764|5.0|Because Danielewski has melded a horror story onto a romance, filtered it through an explication of aesthetics, and plunked it all in a box of mathematical impossibility. In a sense, he's going after the world. One footnote, for example, stretches on for page after page, merely listing names of architects from the past several hundred years. The author has simultaneously cemented his story in the real world and thrown the entirety of the world onto the reader, in a sense daring you to try to absorb and comprehend everything. &quot;House of Leaves&quot; reminds you how much you don't know -- which just adds to the horror that Danielewski wants you to feel.<BR>To tell his story, Danielewski uses a number of typefaces to identify different authors and a variety of typesetting effects (a l e. e. cummings, Ronald Sukenick, et al.) to place you more deeply within the story. He has footnotes all over the place, multiple appendices, collages, two-color text (yes, the title of the book is indeed [pretend &quot;House&quot; is colored blue] &quot;House of Leaves&quot;), even an index, for crying out loud. If you feel the need to see which pages the words &quot;hair&quot; or &quot;melon&quot; appear on, you'll be set.<BR>I know, I know, the book probably sounds like a grab bag of gimmicks, a post-modern stew of pretense that's all style over substance. Don't feel that way. Do yourself a favor and buy, beg, or borrow this book, this &quot;House of Leaves&quot; that took 10 years to build. Don't flip through it, though; force yourself to start at the beginning and hand the reins over to Danielewski. He knows what he's doing.<br />(Also read Chuck Palahniuik books, if you read him instead of House of Leaves, at least your getting closer to hitting bottom [the only place to be].)
1580084621|5.0|After cooking about the fifth dish from this book (&quot;Stir Fried Beef with Spices&quot;) with palate-boggling success , I would like to recommend this book to anybody serious about Thai cooking. While there are no shortcuts (consistent with the author's view to keep things as original as possible) the result is well worth the effort. Some things sound more complicated than they are. Furthermore, this is the first Thai cookbook out of the five or six I have got which explains in detail some really important techniques (like the cracking of coconut cream and why this is important for frying curry pastes). The background chapters are highly recommended.<br />My two open questions are why the Gaeng Panaeng is far from &quot;dry&quot; (with about five cups of coconut milk/cream) and why there is no recipe for Yam Wun Sen (a favourite of my Thai girlfriend, and I thought it was a classic dish). But these are minor points and maybe there is a good reason (I would be curious to learn).<br />All in all: Highly recommended, together with &quot;Vatch&quot; Bhumichitr's books (whose writing style and inside country knowledge I also like very much) my favourite cookbook.
B00000JPHD|5.0|For those modern audiences who have seen Dracula only in the many versions following Bela Lugosi's original interpretation back in 1931, they have been conditioned to focus more on what the Count does than on why he does it.  These reincarnations of the celluloid vampire are rife with hammy acting, multiple vampires, and the quick shock cinematography.  To see the first DRACULA is a lesson on how to scare an audience more with mood than with gory special effects.  Director Tod Browning plucked Bela Lugosi from the stage to reprise Lugosi's role based on the Bram Stoker novel.  Lon Chaney was the original choice, but his unexpected death opened the door for the Hungarian born Lugosi, whose rich accent layered his scenes with an ever present undertow of menace.      The lack of a musical score for nearly all the film requires the audience to focus on the dark sets that begin in the count's castle in Transylvania, then later on the ship that brings him to England, and finally culminates on the dreary streets of a London that emphasized a formless horror.  DRACULA is a film of memorable lines as well.  When Renfield (Dwight Frye) tells the count that he fears the howling of the wolves, Lugosi intones, 'Ah, the children of the night.  What music they make.' Shortly afterwards, Lugosi turns down a glass of sherry with, 'I never drink (pause) wine.'  Such lines as these today could only be played in a campy context, but coming from Lugosi's lips, they resonate with the chilling menace that director Browning clearly intended.  Lugosi was capably backed up by Dwight Frye, who invested his role as Dracula's mad assistant with a maniacal weirdness that lingers even after seven decades.  Helen Chandler as Mina comes across as a victim who seems fascinated by the count even as she clearly recognizes his evil. It is her inner tug that pulls her first one way than another that involves the audience in deciding just where does victimhood ends and willingness begins.  As I watched Mina's matamorphosis from victim to violator, I was reminded on a similar change that Patty Hearst went through fifty years later as a kidnap victim of the Symbionese Liberation Army. The truly outstanding films have the capacity to yank you out of your seat, place you into the action on the screen, and force you to recognize that what you see from the safety of your chair could also happen either to you or to someone else you know.  DRACULA is one such great film.

B0000648WZ|4.0|The reasoning behind some of the details:<br />Everyone in the movie seems American because, if current societal trends are projected into the future, there's a good chance that American English will be the world's universal language. Spanish last names predominate because they represent America's fastest-growing ethnic group.<br />The characters are all good-looking, because people probably will be in the future. If our ancestors saw us, they'd think we were good-looking, since we've had the benefits of modern dentistry and orthodontistry, nutrition, sanitation and hygene. If our civilization lasts, these trends will continue, with the additions of genetic enhancement and cosmetic surgery (already prevelant among the rich).<br />Finally, the gung-ho propaganda is SATIRICAL. 0316666343|5.0|This book is so many things packed into one: lovely, thought-provoking, anger-stirring, frustrating, funny, sad, melancholy, hopeful, helpless, silly, deep and so on.<br />It shoots for greatness, and in my opinion, it falls short.  But only a little short.  The subject matter seems like it would be repellant.  Who wants to read about a raped and murdered 14 year old girl who watches her family go through the incredibly painful grieving process that transforms them all?  There's a nice read for the beach, huh?!?<br />But, Susie Salmon, our narrator, is seldom actually bitter about her death.  She is in heaven (more on that later) and can move through the lives of anyone she wants to, even into their thoughts, at will.  She is always with the living, and she has such love for them that the horrendous grief her family goes through it filtered through this gauze of her love, and thus is made bearable for the reader.  This doesn't mean the book it easy to read...quite the contrary.  There are moments so shattering and immediate that you KNOW you're reading the truth.  You think to  yourself, \\"yep, that's perfectly believable, and I can even see myself doing it.\\"  For example, at one point, Susie tells us how she and her father spent many hours together working on making ships in bottles, something only the two of them ever took interest in in the Salmon family.  But soon after Susie's murder, her father goes to his study and destroys all the ships in a fit of anguish.  The scene is shattering, because we can imagine the depth of the man's torture that would drive him to such an act.<br />What's great about the book is not how grief is depicted in the immediate aftermath of Susie's disappearance, but how that grief continues, and mutates and transforms over time.  Over years.  So many people are affected in ways that they probably can't even trace back to Susie's death, but Susie shows us how.  How her sister ended up with her husband, because shortly after Susie's death, this boy gave her her first kiss to help her with her grief, and that moment bound them together from that point forward.  And this wouldn't have happened without Susie's death.<br />I hope you get the point.  The book is deep at times, yet is sometimes dangerously sentimental and mushy.  And near the end, there's \\"miraculous\\" event (no, nothing so amazing as Susie being resurrected...don't get carried away) which is beautiful on one hand, and on the other hand feels like a bit of a cheat.  The book has struggled so hard to be \\"realistic,\\" (even though we're clearly dealing with the otherworldly, since our narrator is speaking to us from heaven) that this segment skews the book's hard earned credibility.<br />And the descriptions of what heaven is like are a bit iffy.  Sometimes it kind of makes sense, and sometimes I feel the author is just skirting the issue of giving us a more fleshed out idea of her vision of heaven.  In some ways, Susie is so engrossed with earth, she doesn't take the time to really learn about heaven, but even so, I wanted a bit more coherence to those brief segments.  (Although there is a nice moment when her dog joins her.)<br />My criticisms are fairly minor.  In my mind, this book is the best piece of literature dealing with the relationships between the dead and the living since OUR TOWN, and that's saying alot.  There may have been loftier works (C.S. Lewis' THE GREAT DIVORCE comes to mind) but few works are so utterly engrossing and moving.  Once you're two sentences into this book, it's tough to put down.  I read it in near record time for me.  I'm glad I got on the bandwagon for this well-deserved best seller.

B000001GX8|5.0|Karl Bhm had quite an interesting range of specialities, that included among its main objects Wagner, Strauss and Mozart.  While no one needed to convince me of his greatness regarding the former two, I admit that I was somewhat sceptical about his Mozart, especially after having read the previous reviews.  Some people seem to believe that he over-dramatises the opera, and misses the comedy and the joy.  I couldn't disagree more: listening to this recording is an exercise in pure fun, and Bhm never comes even close to boring me.  That being said, it is true that he takes the opera seriously, if that means it does not end up as a farce, and the singers don't sound like a pack of buffi: but that's a plus where I come from!  Joyous comedy need not mean ridicule.<br />I'm not a fan of Fischer-Dieskau when it comes to &quot;heavy&quot; German opera, but here he is more than adequate: I have no problem imagining him as a frustrated &quot;courreur de jupon&quot; of an aristocrat.  I simply do not understand those who complain about his acting. Janowitz for her part not only has the most beautiful voice, she has also been blessed with quite a fair bit of acting genius and musical intelligence, which are evident here.  She and Fidi make quite a pair.<br />Troyanos had a gorgeous dark voice (one that I can actually imagine coming from a young man, granting a certain feminine quality), and her singing here is frankly wonderful, containing a beautiful touch of heartbreaking poetic sadness.  Mathis is a refined, deliciously young sounding Susanna, for whom I have nothing but good things to say.  Hermann Prey is an excellent Figaro as well, mixing candour, ingenuity and anger.    <br />The supporting cast is good, but not particularly memorable (save perhaps for Wohlfahrt, but then again, I'm not sure whether that's a good thing or not).   <br />The remastering for the &quot;The Originals&quot; series is excellent, with relatively few imperfections.  Note also that there areno cuts; if you don't like the usually omitted material from Act IV, stop complaining and just skip it.  <br />Most highly recommended!
0064407667|1.0|I read this book thinking it would be like the wonderful Joan Aiken novels I read as an 11 year old (The Wolves of Willoughby Chase, etc.).  It wasn't.  As a children's librarian, I had seen the growing interest in the series and wanted to be able to endorse it, but I certainly cannot do so.  This series is being pitched to Harry Potter readers, but it lacks the adventure and the aesthetic and moral appeal of J.K. Rowling's books. The creepy freak-show characters and situations were nauseating. The scene where a baby girl tied in ropes is imprisoned in a cage with her mouth taped shut while the cages dangles high above the ground is not the sort of thing I would promote for 10 year olds to read. While the children do manage to overcome their situation, it seems almost by accident.  In the Harry Potter books (and Aiken's fine books), the characters have some character.  They reach heroic stature because they possess compassion, intelligence, bravery, loyalty, moral principles, etc.  Snicket's Baudelaire children are decent kids, but are pathetically powerless and lack the personal qualities that might make them heroic.  The overarching mood is ghoulish and disturbing.  All the adults are presented in a negative way.  The parents \\"abandoned\\" the children via their bizarre death and inadequate plans for their future care.  The executor is a fool who cannot see the writing on the wall.  His wife is pre-occupied and uninterested.  All the adults are either ineffectual or downright sinister.  I feel that the books are frightening to all but very jaded kids because the Baudelaires are such victims and there are no decent adults to aid them.  What a sad commentary.  Harry Potter and gang are nobody's fools.  The adults in the Potter books are a believable and even-handed mix of good and not-so-good.  Rowling, and other great children's authors present children with role models who are winners, not by accident, but because of their integrity.  They present (at least a few!)adults who guide, help and love children.  Snicket's adults ignore or attempt to exploit the children. The Snicket books are awful.

B00003CXI1|3.0|Any comparisions to \\"Chronicles of Narnia\\" or \\"Wizard of Oz\\" are simply erronious and insulting, .... These series are well written and read classics. The word 'classic' does not come to mind when viewing or reading \\"Harry Potter\\". It's an alright book, but not phenomena like \\"C.O.N\\" or \\"W.O.O.\\". Someone pointed out that this drivel will be read again and again, and that makes it classic. Go to it, but good writing will always be the preference of those with taste. Certainly, \\"C.O.N.\\" Chronicles' is moralistic, but more, it's well written, and will be read over and over again (entering a 3rd time, as many will attest).  So too, will 'The Earthsea Trilogy' by LeGuin, and L.O.R. be read over and over again.  However, this should not be a test of a 'Classic' novel; for most people (accurately) consider \\"Moby Dick\\" and \\"War And Peace\\" classics, but few will ever read them more than once.  Who cares if the miraculous happens over and over?  I don't see how it is missing in C.O.N., but then, talking animals and a interdimensional portals to lands full of mythic and magical creatures happens every day in my house.  The miraculous occurs often in a lot of namable dime-store novels and children's books that are long since forgotten by most, (the 'Mushroom Planet' series comes immediately to mind). People read 'Nancy Drew' over and over again, good stories, but not classics. This goes beyond the point of the DVD, but people in search of good fantasy fiction should not be lead to believe this is on the level of these other stories. So, this review addresses the story, which is in both the book and film.<BR>Essentially, in this installment, Harry Potter discovers after growing up a group of \\"muggles\\" (non-magical people, usually displayed as boring and bigoted people by boring and bigoted witches and wizards, the \\"moralization\\" being here that magical people are better somehow, or at least think they are) that he is accepted to a Wizard's School, (a topic given far better treatment in Ursula K. LeGuin's \\"Earthsea Trilogy\\"), and begins his fabulous journey. He arrives at wizard school, and becomes something of a celebrity who quickly rises to the top. He discovers a transparent conspiracy (one that any of the adult magicians should have been able to see) and sets off to solve the mystery.<BR>This movie, like the book that's based on, is fairly boring and superfluous. The tasks Harry has to go through to defeat the villian are not very difficult, and thus not very interesting. It is ludicrous that this series of books and movies are controversial, where it doesn't have anything of true value concerning magic, wizards or witches. Nor does it have interesting lessons, analogies or allusions. <BR>The special effects are fairly clunky CGI work, (watch the centaur scene for jilting movements). The sets and the look of the film are both fantastic, and the 'quiditch' scene is fun to watch, though you never get the sense that Potter is ever in any real danger. The extras on the DVD are silly, and don't warrant a second disc. Though extra scenes are always nice to see.<BR>Though a children's film, there is nothing here to make a comparison to any of the classic stories realistic. It compares better with Nancy Drew or Encyclopedia Brown than some of those that have been loosely thrown about (perchance by people that have not read the series they insult by comparing it to Harry Potter). I actually enjoyed reading Harry Potter's first book though I'm not a child, but there was really nothing warranting the high praise it has gotten aside from good marketing. It just reminds me that there are better children's stories out there, such as the now defunct \\"Mushroom Planet\\" series. This movie is an enjoyable watch, but don't expect \\"Lord of the Rings\\" quality of storytelling.
B00006DEFA|5.0|The quality of this DVD is outstanding. Content-wise, I am a big lover of the theatrical release, and so was a little apprehensive about the director's cut. Some of the added material is just okay, but some of it (such as a scene between Constanza and Salieri, which adds real heft to their meeting at the death-bed scene ) make the director's cut preferable, at least by a slim margin. One thing the added material does not do is in any way \\"ruin\\" the movie,  which I had feared. Less can be more, but here the more is okay, at least in this \\"Amadeus\\"-lover's opinion.  And all added material does have a logic to it---it's not just thrown in for the sake of throwing it in. You can see what the director was thinking, how those scenes function. And the extras here are fascinating. I think this is a terrific buy for the money. VHS was never like this!

B00005QIPH|5.0|... This album - this band - rocks!    I confess that I had never even heard of the Strokes until late in 2002. By then, \\"Is This It\\" had already been out there for an entire year. So, I was oblivious to all this \\"hype\\" I have read about here on Amazon.com... and to these claims that they are \\"The Saviors of Rock and Roll\\". I don't pay all that much attention to this silly stuff put out there by \\"professional\\" music critics.     SO, when my girlfriend informed me one Saturday evening of last year, that \\"some group is playing on SNL tonight... they're supposed to be pretty good...\\", I figured I'd have a look and a listen. That performance was all I needed to watch. I instantly became a Strokes fan and I went out to buy \\"Is This It\\" the next day.    What I like about this band is that, for one, they LOOK like rock and rollers. I know this is not all that important, in the end. But, come on... you have to admit that its tough to get excited by a band that looks more like they should be in a frat house or a haunted house! When you've got \\"the look\\" - and The Strokes have got it(!) - it can only be a plus. But, more importantly - musically - they offer three imperitive elements to good rock and roll. As Carlos Santana once called them, \\"The three S's\\":    1.) Sincerity, 2.) Simplicity, and 3.) Soulfullness.    The songs are infectious, hook-laden, raw, energetic romps. You can tell The Strokes love the music they are playing - it drips out from insdie the CD player! You know from the very first listen whether or not music is pure or pretentious. \\"Is This It\\" is pure rock from the first track to the last.    I'd list the highlights for you, but every track is as good as the next. Of course, the singles \\"Last Nite\\", \\"Someday\\", and \\"Hard To Explain\\" deserve particular attention. But, this is one CD that I will not be skipping over any tracks! It gets played front to back each time I listen to it... and after each listen, it seems to breath new life into itself. This CD ain't getting tired!    I have found it VERY interesting, indeed, how much mud is being slung at The Strokes, and their debut album, on Amazon's customer reviews section! Just this simple fact of how they have stirred up so much attention - and contention - points to this band's importance.    So, take the reviews that show 1 or 2 stars with a grain of salt. Some folks buy into what they hear from rock critics, and as a result they expect way too much... seemingly to forget that EVERYTHING has already been done before in rock and roll. Every new band will be compared to bands that have come before them. But, what The Strokes have done on \\"Is This It\\" is take the rock and roll baton from their predecessors and run with it - further than any band has in a very looooooooooooooooooooong time.    Whether you like them or not, make no mistake - The Strokes are the real deal.

B0000024SI|5.0|Had the album &quot;Blonde On Blonde&quot; never been released, this would be my favorite Dylan album (well now that I think about it, it would be in a tough competition with Blood On The Tracks)....but that's not important. With BIABH he was just getting his feet wet.  With this album he did a cannon-ball right into the ocean.  This is one of Dylan's most freewheelin', feel good bluesy albums.  Dylan rarely sounds like he's having this much fun, and this album rocks.  The lyrics are what you'd expect from the greatest lyricist of all time, the most unique voice in the history of music.  With a rocking band behind him, dylan hits that perfect mix, and the fact that this album isn't even considered his best is staggering.  Highway 61 is an album I revisit many many times, and if you're just new to Dylan, this is definitely a good one to start with, and if anyone tries to call themselves a Dylan fan without this album should be flogged immediately.  Of course this album has one of Dylan's most well known songs, &quot;Like A Rolling Stone,&quot; the one that challenged the radio's conventional 3 minute per song approach.  This album hasn't aged a day, the bluesy feel, and some of Dylan's best singing and inimmitable lyrics (although many have tried) make this as fresh as the day it came out.  remarkable Dylan, but please don't take my word for it, take a trip down Highway 61.

B000002UAX|5.0|When one rates Beatles record, it seems almost natural that one tends to compare each one against the Beatles' own catalog. It's almost understood that it would be a waste of time to compare their work vs. other musicians. So - where does that leave the White Album?<br />Well, it's one of the best in it's own disjointed and fractured manner. This is the Beatles as solo artists. A band not sure that they wanted to still be together but certain that they couldn't separate. Most songs were recorded by small pairings of the band. Or solo, such as Paul's \\"Why don't we do it in the Road?\\"  Still, the band is structured enough to offer a record that moves in jerky ways this way and that but still maintains the essence of the group.<br />John Lennon seems to sum up the overall mood of the band in his \\"I'm so Tired\\" The album has a feeling of weariness at the odd world the band inhabited. The times were definitely changing and the boys sounded like they had become disillusioned with some of their utopian fancy. Not that this is a bad thing...<br />So why ramble on. This is a tough gritty album with many classics and a few second rate offerings that I know am happy to have. Let's face it, the Beatles at less then their best are better than just about anyone else.  This record is an important snapshot of a band maturing and groping towards their final burst of unity and dissolution.
0425152251|2.0|SOPHIE'S WORLD comes with one of those &quot;discussion guides&quot; with all sorts of thought-provoking or nausea-inducing questions in the back. The first question asks &quot;Is Sophie special or unusual, or can anyone become a good philosopher?&quot;<br />I hated that question when I first read it, but it does open up further questions. What is Sophie? Is she a character in Gaarder's novel? Or is she an object, a projection, not even worthy of the few considerations that we grant a character? She certainly acts like an automaton.<br />Gaarder's book alleges itself to be a novel of the history of philosophy. Unfortunately, it barely stands up to the critical examination due a novel. The plot is non-existent. The characters are flimsy playthings. Sophie and should-be-creepy mentor Alberto Knox become philosophy salad-shooters, taking the ingredients that are the basis of Western Philosophy, and spouting them out in slightly tasty but good-for-you servings.<br />I am in no way qualified to judge the History of Philosophy aspect of this book, but I suspect that Eastern philosophies are given short shrift. I also share some other reviewers' regret that Sartre marks the end into the exploration into the 20th century. The novel's &quot;twist&quot; coincides with the discussion of the philosopher that is the publisher's namesake, and this twist serves to both reduce whatever miniscule investment the reader may have placed on the paper-thin characters, while distracting from the object of relating the last sequence of philosophers.<br />One thing about SOPHIE'S WORLD is that it is a very international book. My Chinese classmates tell me they read the book. The author and the characters are Norwegian, and one of the characters serves as a UN Peacekeeper. The UN is an interesting representation of global ideals, and it is interesting to see in current events how much weight it carries. SOPHIE'S WORLD wears its hopes for the UN on its sleeves, and it just underscores how depressing it is that so many in the United States would just as soon see the UN rendered irrelevant.

0395925037|5.0|Part biography, part party manifesto and part propoganda pamphlet, \\"Mein Kampf\\" (\\"My Struggle\\") is three volumes of a work first published in 1925 while the Little Corporal was just that, an obscure agitator serving a brief prison sentence for a failed coup (putsch) in Munich. Manheim's translation of \\"Mein Kampf\\" is perhaps the best one so far. He does an excellent job translating many of the German metaphors into English. Don't feel guilty about buying this book. Having it on your bookshelf doesn't make you a Nazi sympathizer. So go on, buy it, read it and remember that those who ignore history are condemned to repeat it.
B00005QG9J|3.0|It's hard to complain about this release when the second half of 2001 saw airwaves dominated by the endless drone of bland corporate acts like Nickelback and Puddle of Mudd. On the other hand, this album truly has disappointed me, mainly because it comes from a band I know can do better. <br />I don't want to simplify things to much, but here is basically how I look at the three major Incubus releases: S.C.I.E.N.C.E. was a very solid and very original effort that made for a fun listen; this album (MORNING VIEW) is a very toned-down Incubus that was obviously tempted to tread into softer and more mainstream territory by the success of their previous album's softest songs (&quot;Drive&quot; and &quot;Stellar&quot;); and MAKE YOURSELF was the middle album where both elements came together to create an exceptional, if not classic, record.<br />The first complaint I have with this release, aside from the obvious change in style intended to draw 15 year old girls into the fan base, is the lack of any exceptional/standout tracks. Where are the classic songs that we found on SCIENCE (&quot;New Skin&quot; and &quot;Certain Shade of Green&quot;) and MAKE YOURSELF (&quot;Pardon Me&quot; and &quot;Nowhere Fast&quot;)? It seems that with MORNING VIEW, Incubus has thrown together a collection of songs in which about half are what I would deem 'pretty good' (such as &quot;Nice to Know You,&quot; &quot;Blood on the Ground,&quot; and &quot;Warning&quot;), and the other half are more mediocre (&quot;Wish You Were Here&quot; and &quot;11 am&quot;).<br />While there are sure to be plenty of fans, especially newer ones, that argue that this new, softer Incubus is simply a more mature version of the older sound, I would respond that MAKE YOURSELF featured a sound that worked and sounded much better, while still showing at least as much musical and lyrical maturity. The song structures and lyrics on MORNING VIEW have *not* (IMO) become any more sophisticated; the real difference is a shift in style towards the MTV crowd.<br />With all that said, I still listen to this record sometimes, and find it to be one of the top 10 rock releases of 2001. It's hard to deliver something that matches the quality of MAKE YOURSELF, so perhaps I was expecting a little too much. After all, there are at least four or five songs on here that recall MAKE YOURSELF to some extent and make for a good listen. My worry is that if this trend continues, the next Incubus release will be full of &quot;Mexico's&quot; and &quot;Echo's,&quot; which will officially qualify as selling out for me. Until then, I'll enjoy MAKE YOURSELF and SCIENCE often, and I'll throw MORNING VIEW in the CD player when I'm tired of those.

B00004LN16|5.0|There exists today an entire army of reviewers ready to dismiss every AC/DC outing as &quot;the same old thing.&quot;<br />There is no problem with &quot;the same old thing&quot; when the same old thing is simple perfection. By contrast, the last few AC/DC albums have suffered from a bit of an identity crisis; they attempted to layer heavy-handed production on what is essentialy a straight-ahead blues band, more closely related to B.B. King than to the mass of '80s hair-metal bands that are all but extinct today.<br />George Young's production on Stiff Upper Lip brings to the forefront those strengths which make AC/DC the undisputed kings of blues-metal: the Young brothers' simple, undeniable blue-collar riffs and Malcolm Young's working-class voice. Tracks like Stiff Upper Lip and Hold Me Back are toe-tapping, head-bobbing, hammer-pounding hard-working songs the likes of which can be found nowhere else in record stores today. There hasn't been an AC/DC album (or indeed any album) like this in years, and that's a shame.<br />What a good thing we have this one to listen to!

B000002UAI|4.0|This is one of the Beatles' most underrated albums.  I'll admit it probably would've been a stronger album with more originals but it does have some good covers (this was the end of an era since as the Beatles wrote more of their own songs, the covers would disappear, though there were a few on Help!).  This album was recorded in the midst of the Beatles touring and released in time for Christmas in 1964 in the UK (Americans would get sections of it on Beatles '65 and Beatles VI).  You can almost see the wear and tear on the Beatles' faces on the cover.  Derek Taylor mixes articulation with humour on the liner notes (the  wisecrack included in this review's title is an example of his wit).  <br />The album opens with the melancholy \\"No Reply,\\" in which John offers his evasive girlfriend one more chance (lots of acoustic guitar work on this).  \\"I'm a Loser\\" is a fun song, although the lyrics have gotten grimmer (John feels like a fool and feels sorry for himself).  You can hear the Dylan influence with the acoustic guitars and harmonica (with a touch of Carl Perkins on the guitar solo).  Also, John throws in some philosophy \\"And so it's true pride comes before a fall.\\"  \\"Baby's In Black\\" sounds almost like the woman who dumped John is about to get her due from another guy as he sings \\"Oh how long will it take 'till she sees the mistake she has made?\\" (these 3 songs almost sound related!).  \\"Rock and Roll Music\\" is perhaps the strongest cover with John, Paul and George Martin on piano with this Chuck Berry classic (if you remember The Compleat Beatles documentary, it's the opening track) while \\"Mr. Moonlight\\" is the weakest (the Hammond organ makes their reading sound dated).  \\"Words of Love\\" is fun and catchy.  Paul combines 2 classics \\"Kansas City/Hey, Hey, Hey Hey\\" and there are 2 Carl Perkins numbers- \\"Honey Don't\\" (sung by Ringo) and \\"Everybody's Trying to Be My Baby\\" (sung by George).  \\"I'll Follow the Sun\\" was supposedly written by Paul back in the 1950's whenhe was with the Quarreymen.  \\"Every Little Thing\\" sports an interesting melody with some fine harmonies by John and Paul (one of two happier love songs here).  \\"Eight Days a Week\\" (the other happier love song) is even catchier with the 1st ever fade-in in history (the title came from something Ringo said \\"We've been working eight, I mean seven days a week!\\").  \\"I Don't Want to Spoil the Party\\" shows John in desparation (lyrically belying a chipper melody), while hoping against hope (\\"If she shows up while I'm gone, please let me know\\").  \\"What You're Doing\\" (sung by Paul) features some Spector-like drums (in the mold of \\"Be My Baby\\") and the opening guitar riff sounds like it inspired the Byrds on their version of \\"Mr. Tambourine Man.\\" <br />To quote Mr. Taylor: \\"The kids of AD 2000 will draw from the music the same sense of well being and warmth as we do today.\\"  It's amazing how prophetic these words which were written in late 1964 have become!

You can hear the Dylan influence with the acoustic guitars and harmonica (with a touch of Carl Perkins on the guitar solo). 038533348X|4.0|Obvious satire on all the ridiculous happy endings sewn onto stories but why else throw in the towel on mankind?   One wonders if the story might be a justification for suicide.   One supposes that Vonnegut, like his character, little Newt, was disappointed that in making a Cat's Cradle that there really is no cat and no cradle-that there is really nothing supporting the religious tripe that seem to keep people rolling down the track.  He certainly put the \\"dys\\" in utopia here.  I doubt if a more poignant tale of futility and hopelessness could be penned.<br /> Although his memorable characters are nicely drawn-they are all too easily erased by the final page.  Why struggle through so many pages of words only to reach the same blank page one started with?  Looking for virtue in the tale one can say that it was short and abrupt.  The suffering doesn't last that long.  Everyone would prefer an instant and painless end to their life.
